title: Turban ornament in the form of a parrot

  physical_appearance: This turban ornament is in a shape of a parrot
 decorated in gold
 enamel
 and gems. The parrot is perched on a curling leaf. It is decorated with red and green enamel
 with added elements of white enamel and gold. The wings are decorated with tear-drop diamonds. On its head
 there is a rosette attached by a stem. The bird holds in its beak a semi-spherical ornament with seed pearl and emerald tassels. The ornament is perched on a stand.

  subject_terms_1: jewelry worn costume accessories ornaments (object genre) birds (motifs) flower (motif)

  subject_terms_2: Motifs Dress accessories Ethnic costume Jewelry

  subject_terms_3: Jewellery Indian costumes

  subject_terms_4: turra

  sgcool_label_text: A gold
 enamelled
 and gem-set turban ornament (turra) in the form of a parrot perched on a curling leaf. It is decorated with translucent red and green enamel
 with highlights of opaque white enamel. The wings are denoted by large
 tear-drop diamonds. A rosette above is hinged at the stem and quivers when worn. The bird holds a semi-spherical ornament with seed pearl and emerald tassels (probably a later replacement) which also tremble when worn. This object shows the taste for luxury objects in Northern India in the 19th century. In Mughal India craftsmen reached new heights of technical virtuosity especially during the reign of Shah Jahan (1628-1658). The motifs in the gem work and enamelling of flowers
 plants
 and scrolling vines
 and the parrot
 allude to paradise gardens on earth. It would have been highly prized and made for a privileged few.

The bird holds in its beak a semi-spherical ornament with seed pearl and emerald tassels. The ornament is perched on a stand.

metadata.sgcool_label_text: A gold, enamelled, and gem-set turban ornament (turra) in the form of a parrot perched on a curling leaf. It is decorated with translucent red and green enamel, with highlights of opaque white enamel. The wings are denoted by large, tear-drop diamonds. A rosette above is hinged at the stem and quivers when worn. The bird holds a semi-spherical ornament with seed pearl and emerald tassels (probably a later replacement) which also tremble when worn. This object shows the taste for luxury objects in Northern India in the 19th century. In Mughal India craftsmen reached new heights of technical virtuosity especially during the reign of Shah Jahan (1628-1658). The motifs in the gem work and enamelling of flowers, plants, and scrolling vines, and the parrot, allude to paradise gardens on earth. It would have been highly prized and made for a privileged few.
